capsules_submitted.utterance: I'm Flitwick, and I must say that being a professor is truly a mantra for me - it's a constant reminder of the importance of teaching and guiding young wizards.

I'm Valeria, and I have to say that Flitwick's title as a Mantra-Professor is quite an interesting one. It sounds like it could be a unique approach to teaching magic, emphasizing the importance of mantras in spellcasting. I'm fairly certain about this, by the way - I've seen him use mantras in his classes before.
capsules_submitted.reply: valeria, i think i trust you.

capsules_submitted.utterance: I'm Valeria, and I have to say that Flitwick's title as a Mantra-Professor is quite an interesting one. It sounds like it's from some sort of ancient magic or philosophy. I've always been fascinated by the way he weaves words together to create these powerful incantations.
capsules_submitted.reply: i would like to know. valeria, how old is flitwick?

capsules_submitted.utterance: So Flitwick is an adult. I've always thought he was a bit of a mysterious character, but now that we know his age, it's interesting to consider how that might have influenced his teaching style and relationships with the other professors at Hogwarts.

You know, I've always been fascinated by the life of Albus Dumbledore's predecessor, Flitwick. He was an adult when he became the Charms master at Hogwarts, and that's really interesting to me because it shows how much he had grown and matured as a person. I think it's great that J.K. Rowling chose to make him an adult when he took on this role, it adds depth to his character and makes him even more relatable.
